results.title: Let's get Skase
results.creator_credit: Matthew George, Colin South, John Tatoulis, Film Finance Corporation Australia, Lotteries Commission of Western Australia, Media World Features and ScreenWest
results.brief_description: A quirky adventure-comedy based on the alleged “true story” of one man’s attempt to kidnap failed Australian businessman Christopher Skase. When Peter Dellasandro (Lachy Hulme) convinces the creditors of the Quintex Empire to fund a covert mission to send a crack team of experts to Majorca to kidnap Skase and return him to Australia things don’t go quite as he planned. What his crack team of misfits lack in skill, they make up for in enthusiasm. Cast includes Craig McLachlan, who stars as Eric Carney, host of a reality TV program who is mounting his own mission to ‘get Skase’, and Alex Dimitriades as Danny D’Amato, Dellasandro’s right-hand man.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Matthew George, Colin South, John Tatoulis, Film Finance Corporation Australia, Lotteries Commission of Western Australia, Media World Features and ScreenWest

results.title: Ali
results.creator_credit: Michael Mann, A. Kitman Ho, James Lassiter, Jon Peters, Paul Ardaji and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Michael Mann’s sprawling bio pic tries to cover big ground with this iconoclastic boxing figure. The results are more like a greatest hits as Mann tracks Ali’s rise in the boxing world and his status as a potent force in black politics. Will Smith inhabits the towering frame of Ali quite convincingly, turning in a performance which is more like a collage of Ali sound bytes. Along the way we become privy to some of the most influential and turbulent political movements in America; through Ali’s controversial association with activist Malcolm X, his conversion to Islam and his uncompromising anti-Vietnam war stance. While less savory aspects of Ali’s life (like his notorious womanizing) are left pretty much alone. Ali also draws on the mythical boxing match ‘Rumble in the jungle’ which was also the subject of the compelling documentary ‘When we were kings’. Cast includes: Jada Pinkett Smith, Jamie Foxx, Ron Silver, Jon Voight, Mario Van Peebles, Jeffrey Wright.

results.title: Mulholland Drive
results.creator_credit: David Lynch, Alain Sarde, Mary Sweeney, Michael Polaire, Neal Edelstein, Tony Krantz, Asymmetrical Productions, Imagine Television, Les Films Alain Sarde, Picture Factory and Studio Canal+
results.brief_description: Betty Elms (Naomi Watts) has arrived in Hollywood dreaming of being a star. But when she goes to stay at her Aunt’s apartment she finds it occupied by the lovely Rita (Laura Elena Harring) who has lost her memory and is terrified for her life. From the most basic of plots and narrative cliche, David Lynch furnishes a deeply troubling and deeply erotic investigation of Hollywood, a vision which has the logic and texture of a hallucinatory dream. Both Betty and Rita, and their alter egos, Diane and Camilla, embody competing versions of celebrity and fame: movies as success and Hollywood as destruction. But attempting to explain “Mulholland Drive” in linear terms is self-defeating. A continuation of Lynch’s ground-breaking work in “Blue Velvet”, “Twin Peaks” and “Lost Highway”, the surreal sequences in the film are never excessively melodramatic or ridiculous; they are often moving and chilling. Lynch creates a singularly impressive mise-en-scene of the unconscious which places him in the forefront of contemporary cinema. “Mulholland Drive” began as a pilot for a TV series. When the producers were alarmed by Lynch’s work, they cancelled the series. Fortunately, Lynch was able to eventually secure funding from European production sources. But this difficult genesis and production history has been written into the final film itself, where the Machiavellian game which is filmmaking in Hollywood is re-cast in stark visual metaphors of good and of evil. In Lynch’s universe, the Devil is a cowboy.

results.title: Ronin [DVD]
results.creator_credit: John Frankenheimer, Frank Mancuso, FGM Entertainment and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: Told proficiently, “Ronin” is an action/thriller about a group of renegade criminals for hire, a gang of international professional thieves and killers, without allegiances to country or cause. Deirdre, a mysterious Irish woman, organises a crack team for one high-risk job - to steal a valuable case of unknown contents. The team consists of an ex-CIA officer, a former European intelligence officer, a skilled driver, a top electronics expert and a weapons specialist. The five don’t know, like or particularly trust one another but must work together to get the job done. Director Frankenheimer, somewhat of an expert in the field of car chase sequences, flexes his knowledge here with spectacular rides through the narrow streets of Paris and Cannes. Pyrotechnics, rolling cars, shootouts and a minor love interest make “Ronin” a fairly standard crime movie with some very impressive stunts. International cast includes: Robert De Niro, Natascha McElhone, Stellan Skarsgard, Jonathon Pryce and Jean Reno. Script is by David Mamet (The Winslow boy, Hannibal, State and Main) working under the pseudonym Richard Weisz.

results.title: Zoolander [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Ben Stiller, Scott Rudin, Stuart Cornfeld, Paramount Pictures, VH1 Films and Village Roadshow Pictures
results.brief_description: Ben Stiller directed, co-wrote and starred in this comedy, which spoofs the world of male models. The idea, which began as a Stiller skit in 1996, is teased into a feature length film. The story centres on Derek Zoolander (Stiller) - a famous male model, three-time winner of model of the year and creator of several iconic looks including Le Tigre and Blue steel. Derek’s reign is threatened by the rise of Hansel McDonald (Owen Wilson) a male model whose freewheeling attitude makes him hotter than the 90s flavoured Derek. The plot centres on rivalry between the two models and the assassination of the Malaysian Prime Minister, whose new anti-child labour laws threatens the lucrative fashion trade. “Zoolander” satirises modelling, beauty, the cult of celebrity, nightclubs, MTV and VH1 type of fashion awards. One of the sharpest sequences in the film is a ‘walk-off’ between the two models, judged by none other than David Bowie. Numerous film references are peppered throughout including - 2001: A Space odyssey, the X-Files, the Manchurian candidate and Trading places. Cast includes: Jerry Stiller, David Duchovny, Vince Vaughn, Christine Taylor and Will Ferrell, with cameos by Billy Zane, Wynona Ryder, Donald Trump, Christina Slater, Lenny Kravitz, Gwen Stefani and Donatella Versace.

results.title: Lantana (Special edition) [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Ray Lawrence, Mandy Walker, Jan Chapman, Film Finance Corporation Australia, MBP and Saddleback Productions
results.brief_description: Ray Lawrence (Bliss) returned to filmmaking after a sixteen-year absence to direct “Lantana”. Adapted from his own play, scriptwriter Andrew Bovell depicts a dozen characters, reflecting a prism of modern day Sydney. One woman’s death - perhaps murder - sparks a crisis in a series on interconnecting relationships. Leon is a policeman investigating the woman’s disappearance, who’s emotional stolidity is reflected in his violent dealings with clients; his aging wife Sonja seeks counselling for her desolate personal state; her therapist Valerie, is struggling to cope with the death of her teenage daughter and the deterioration of her marriage to John, an emotionally remote academic; Jane, a lonely and aimless woman, is estranged from her husband Pete and seeks sex with Leon. Miscommunication and secret trysts (real and imagined) leads characters to draw false conclusions. Several red herrings increase the intensity of the murder mystery, but the real concern of the film is the kaleidoscope of human failings and interactions, reflecting a complex interweaving of intent and desire. Paul Kelly’s score serves as an effective moody soundtrack to the film. Winner of seven AFI awards. Cinematography by Mandy Walker. Cast includes Anthony La Paglia, Geoffrey Rush, Barbara Hershey, Kerry Armstrong, Rachael Blake, Vince Colosimo, Peter Phelps, Leah Purcell, Glenn Robins.

results.title: The Entity
results.creator_credit: Sidney J. Furie, Harold Schneider, American Cinema Productions and Pelleport Investors
results.brief_description: This horror/haunted house/poltergeist movie is based on a true story of a woman who was harassed by inexplicable forces. Carla Moran (Barbara Hershey) is a caring mother who lives with her children, when she is repeatedly and brutally raped by an unseen entity, and besieged by other inconceivable events that petrify her. Carla is increasingly isolated (even ridiculed) for her experiences, which rack her emotionally and physically. When she seeks professional help, a team of psychiatrists study Carla’s situation seeking to unravel the source of her terror. Some sceptics in the team believe it to be female hysteria even insanity, but one kindly doctor, Phil Schneidermann (Ron Silver) is convinced of her sincerity and is determined to aid her plight with science and a parapsychological approach. At times genuinely terrifying, this film is somewhat dated, particularly in the special effects department, but interestingly was released just a year before Spielberg’s hugely successful “Poltergeist”, with which it shares many major themes. Hershey puts in a fine performance as an imperilled woman whose ordinary (if bleak) life is put under siege by forces beyond her comprehension. Although the film takes a somewhat dissatisfying turn mid-way through, it remains an interesting example of a science versus spirit movie and should prove a boon to horror buffs.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sidney J. Furie, Harold Schneider, American Cinema Productions and Pelleport Investors

results.title: Sexy beast
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Glazer, Jeremy Thomas, Film Four International, Fox Searchlight Pictures and Kanzaman S A
results.brief_description: Gary (Ray Winstone) is a retired criminal, living in a luxurious Spanish villa with his ex-porn star wife and a couple of choice friends. The news of the impending arrival of Don (Ben Kingsley) - a former colleague of Don’s and a psychopath, puts the group on knife-edge. Don descends on the group like a hurricane - spewing foul language and oozing menace. His mission is to bring Gary back to London for a jewellery heist, masterminded by Teddy Bass (Ian MacShane). Gary’s refusal means little to Don as he cajoles, threatens, prods and manipulates Gary into taking the job. Don also works on intimidating the group, who are catatonic with fear and are on a helpless mission not to evoke Don’s anger. “Sexy beast” is a thriller/crime film that has a kinetic style that is at times reminiscent of Guy Ritchie. This film was Jonathon Glazer’s debut feature and Ben Kingsley was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Actor.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jonathan Glazer, Jeremy Thomas, Film Four International, Fox Searchlight Pictures and Kanzaman S A

Don descends on the group like a hurricane - spewing foul language and oozing menace. His mission is to bring Gary back to London for a jewellery heist, masterminded by Teddy Bass (Ian MacShane). Gary’s refusal means little to Don as he cajoles, threatens, prods and manipulates Gary into taking the job. Don also works on intimidating the group, who are catatonic with fear and are on a helpless mission not to evoke Don’s anger. “Sexy beast” is a thriller/crime film that has a kinetic style that is at times reminiscent of Guy Ritchie. This film was Jonathon Glazer’s debut feature and Ben Kingsley was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Actor.
description_for_label: Gary (Ray Winstone) is a retired criminal, living in a luxurious Spanish villa with his ex-porn star wife and a couple of choice friends. The news of the impending arrival of Don (Ben Kingsley) - a former colleague of Don’s and a psychopath, puts the group on knife-edge. Don descends on the group like a hurricane - spewing foul language and oozing menace. His mission is to bring Gary back to London for a jewellery heist, masterminded by Teddy Bass (Ian MacShane). Gary’s refusal means little to Don as he cajoles, threatens, prods and manipulates Gary into taking the job. Don also works on intimidating the group, who are catatonic with fear and are on a helpless mission not to evoke Don’s anger. “Sexy beast” is a thriller/crime film that has a kinetic style that is at times reminiscent of Guy Ritchie. This film was Jonathon Glazer’s debut feature and Ben Kingsley was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Actor.

results.title: Wall Street
results.creator_credit: Oliver Stone, Edward Pressman and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Skinny neckties and double-breasted suits adorn Wall Street, which follows the path of Bud Fox (Charlie Sheen) into a milieu of corporate capitalism. He soon realises to stay in this new world with high-powered corporate espionage player Gordon Gekko (Michael Douglas) he must break a few rules. Gekko represents one of three father figures for Fox, the other two being his real father and his boss at the broking firm, all of whom give him constant advice. However, Fox’s overwhelming desire for gold cufflinks and brick-like cellular phones steer him down the path of corruption and greed and he soon realises the price of the pursuit of overnight success. Director Oliver Stone captures the hectic hum of the commerce world and encapsulates the greed that is synonymous with the rise of capitalism in the 1980s. Michael Douglas received an Oscar for Best Actor at the 1987 Academy Awards for his role as Gekko.

results.title: Voyage to the bottom on the sea
results.creator_credit: Irwin Allen, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Windsor Productions
results.brief_description: Atmospheric adventure film and science fiction classic, “Voyage to the bottom of the sea” tells of a routine scientific exploration mission to the North Pole which goes horribly awry. The submarine crew, helmed by Admiral Harriman Nelson, a taciturn old-school navy man, are alarmed to discover that the Van Allen radiation belt has been ignited by a freak meteor shower, and the earth and sky are afire. Nelson, at loggerheads with his deputy, makes the inflammatory decision to extinguish the inferno by detonating a nuclear missile. Despite the censure of the United Nations, Nelson presses ahead with his scheme, whilst combating natural disasters, mutiny, giant sea creatures and a religious zealot on board. This film won many accolades for its special effects (state-of-the-art for its day), with a screenplay reflective of public concerns about potential apocalyptic nuclear disasters.
